grammar.explanation: Short answers can use the verbs 'er', 'har', 'kan', 'skal', 'må', and 'vil'. Everything else must use 'gør' (meaning 'do').
examples: A: Bor du i københavn? B: Ja, det gør jeg.
A: Kan du tale dansk? B: Ja, det kan jeg.

grammar.explanation: På and I are prepositions. There are no good rules for when to use them. På is more like 'on' and I is more like 'in'.
examples: Har du været på arbejde i dag? (Arbejde is always 'på')
Har du været i skole i dag. (Skole is always 'i')
Jeg bor i København (Cities are typically 'i')
Jeg bor i Valby (Some neighbourhoods are historically cities)
Jeg bor på Amager (Islands are typically 'på')

grammar.explanation: 'Henne' is a positional adverb. 'Hen' is a directional adverb
examples: Hvor bor du henne? (Where do you live [at]?)
Hvor går du hen? (Where are you walking [to]?)

grammar.explanation: Hjem/Hjemme (home) is special, like in English. We don't say 'I am going to home', we say, 'I am going home'. 'Hjemme' is positional, 'Hjem' is directional.
Central adverbs like 'ikke', 'aldrig', 'altid' come between the verb and the noun.
examples: Jeg spiser ikke brød (I don't eat bread)
Jeg drikke altid kaffe i morgen (I always drink coffee in the morning)
Jeg spiser aldrig morgenmad (I never eat breakfast)
